Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome
to this meeting in public of the Board of

14.text:
NHS England. A very warm welcome to those
members of the public who have joined us here

20.text:
in the meeting room in London, and also to
our global audience as we stream the proceedings

26.text:
live, just simply as testament to our commitment
to doing our formal business in public. By

33.text:
the way, that means, particularly on this
morning’s agenda, there are some very chunky,

38.text:
difficult items that we will be discussing
and coming to a decision on. Just to emphasise

45.text:
again that the Board works in many ways, and
we try to ensure that non-executives and executive

51.text:
members of the Board come together in early-stage
discussions about the future strategy for

57.text:
NHS England. For example, we had a development
session yesterday afternoon where we looked

62.text:
at progress on various fronts and tried to
think our way through some very important

69.text:
issues such as the future of the devolution
agenda, for example. Those are by and large

74.text:
items that will come to future meetings of
the Board of NHS England. So this morning,

95.text:
the Board.
Also, to emphasise what the meeting is. It

100.text:
is a meeting in public. It is not a public
meeting; it is a meeting in which the Board

105.text:
will be discussing. We will not be engaging
in broader discussion, but if anybody who

111.text:
is here in the audience today would like to
discuss with us after the meeting any of these

115.text:
items informally, we would be very pleased
to do so.

118.text:
I am going to declare now the meeting formally
opened, and to invite from my colleagues any

126.text:
declarations of interest in matters on the
agenda. I need to make a declaration, which

132.text:
is in respect of the paper on congenital heart
disease, which makes reference to two organisations.

140.text:
One is the National Institute for Cardiovascular
Outcomes Research, and the other one is the

145.text:
Clinical Operational Research Unit, both of
them based at UCL, of which I was the president

151.text:
and provost. Just to assure the Board I have
had no engagement with either of those two

155.text:
organisations since I retired from UCL two
years ago. May I invite any other declarations

161.text:
of interest from the Board?
It is a similar declaration, in the sense

167.text:
that I set up NICOR when I was at UCL.
The Congenital Heart Disease Review; I have

173.text:
had a longstanding relationship with the team
in Newcastle and nationally, but I have not

178.text:
had any direct involvement with this report.
Good, thank you. Any other declarations of

182.text:
interest? This is in addition, of course,
to those standing declarations which are recorded

186.text:
on the register. Good, thank you very much.
I now would like to record apologies for absence.

194.text:
We have an apology from David Roberts. Just
to emphasise, yet again, that this is a conflict

198.text:
of timing. Today, David will be at the Annual
General Meeting of Nationwide, where he will

204.text:
be declared to be the new chairman of Nationwide.
So is not able to be with us this morning,

211.text:
but he has had an input to the business of
the Board.

217.text:
We have at item 12 reports from Board Committees.
Normally, these are starred items, and I invite

224.text:
members of the Board to unstar them. I understand
that what we would wish to do this morning

229.text:
is to take three of them as simple reports
which are taken as read, but on the Specialised

234.text:
Services Committee I will invite Gordon to
say a few words about the recent deliberations

240.text:
of that Committee. Can I just stress to the
Board to anybody who wants to unstar any of

243.text:
those items through the meeting when we get
to there, that is entirely within our power.

251.text:
May I then move on to the minutes of the last
meeting and ask you to approve them as an

257.text:
accurate record? Thank you. I have had no
notice of any matters arising. Are there any

263.text:
other matters arising? No, there are not.
Thank you very much.

267.text:
Before we move to the Chief Executive’s
Report, may I just raise one or two preliminary

272.text:
items from the Chair? The first of them is
to record the indication that we have from

280.text:
Dame Barbara Hakin of her retirement, and
to ask the Board to support my proposal that

287.text:
we at this stage record our warmest thanks
to Barbara for everything that she has done.

292.text:
I have to say that, personally, I have worked
with Barbara quite closely over the last four

296.text:
years, and I think much of my task would have
been much more difficult if not undoable without

302.text:
the constant personal and warm support that
I have had from Barbara, who has worked in

307.text:
the NHS in many various guises for over 40
years. It is an extraordinary career. Barbara,

314.text:
we are not losing you yet, but it would be
I think wrong for us not this morning to record

320.text:
our enormous gratitude and appreciation for
all that you have done.

325.text:
Second, by way of preliminary business, is
to report, following the speech by the Secretary

332.text:
of State last week, on the proposal that the
government has to draw together TDA and Monitor,

340.text:
and to have appointed as the Chairman of the
new organisation Ed Smith, who presently serves

348.text:
on this Board as our Vice Chairman, and also
Chair of Audit and Risk Committee. I think

354.text:
it is obvious to everybody that there could
not have been a better choice of chairman,

358.text:
whilst at the same time, we appreciate the
sheer complexity of the role, and frankly,

363.text:
the sheer importance of the new body NHS Improvement
in assisting us in partnership with them to

372.text:
deliver more effectively the mission that
we all share, which is improving the quality

377.text:
and efficiency of the NHS for patients across
the country. We will lose Ed I think probably

385.text:
about the end of October, because I am very
keen that we should have a transition, and

389.text:
I will be discussing with members of the Board
the implications and the knock-on consequences

395.text:
for activity within the Board. Ed, at this
stage, may we please extend to you our warmest

401.text:
congratulations on that appointment and our
determination to continue to work closely

406.text:
with you.
Just very briefly to note that in the New

412.text:
Year’s Honours List this year, there were
awards of a knighthood to Ciarán Devane,

418.text:
a citation which particularly mentions his
outstanding contribution to supporting cancer

423.text:
patients at Macmillan Cancer Support. In 2013,
Macmillan reached 5.2 million people and recruited

431.text:
405,000 new supporters. That I think is a
wonderful public recognition of a superb career

440.text:
and those qualities that you have also brought
to our Board, Ciarán. Our warmest congratulations

445.text:
to you. I would join in those congratulation
Richard Jeavons, who has been our Director

451.text:
for Specialised Commissioning on secondment,
who was awarded a CBE.

456.text:
If I am in such wonderful territory, I might
just touch upon the University of Birmingham,

463.text:
which is one of the finest talent-spotting
organisations in the country, because at its

469.text:
honorary degree ceremony last week it conferred
honorary degrees upon Ed Smith, Simon Stevens

475.text:
and Victor, and the Board I think would like
to reflect the hat-trick that is represented

481.text:
in the University of Birmingham’s proceedings.
And the discovery of the oldest copy of the

485.text:
Quran was unrelated to that set of activities;
important nonetheless.

490.text:
Well, I think we all recognise that the University
of Birmingham is one of the finest universities
